indicators.justification:
Moldova has no systematic approach to
comprehensive and efficient collection of data
on hazard extent and intensity after an event. A common shared platform dedicated to multihazard risk information, including exposure and
vulnerability data, should be developed and
needs to be available to all relevant ministries
and agencies. Disaster Risk Management risk assessments should be mainstreamed into sectoral development strategies. This change would facilitate greater coordination in data sharing and management
and help meet priorities such as seismic risk
mapping and the development of a national
database of infrastructure and buildings and
their vulnerabilities. (1)

indicators.justification:
The Open Budget Survey 2019 ranking shows that, in terms of budgetary transparency, the Republic of Moldova registers the score of 57 points out of 100. The result indicates a limited disclosure of information on budget documents and places the Republic of Moldova on the 39th place out of 117 countries that were included in the evaluation. OBS 2019 shows an increase in the detail of budget documents, in particular annual reports, although the authorities remain lagging behind in preparing and publishing mid-year reports and also in terms of budgetary discipline.(1)

The BOOST database of government spending has been constantly but slowly updated. The latest data from BOOST is from 2019, as the ministry does not have enough human and financial resources to manage the process at a faster pace. (2)

Data on budget execution is being published by the Ministry of Finance on the open data portal date.gov.md. The data is updated on a monthly basis. (3)

Users can navigate through data about National Public Budget through an interactive tool data that creates data visualization on budget execution. The portal was launched by the Ministry of Finance. (4)

Sources:
1) Press release Open budget survey 2019 Moldova 
https://www.expert-grup.org/ro/activitate/comunicate-de-presa/item/1962-potrivit-open-budget-survey-2019-republica-moldova-bate-pasul-pe-loc-la-capitolul-transparentei-bugetare
2) Public expenditure database Boost
https://mf.gov.md/ro/content/analiza-cheltuielilor-2009-2019
3) Data on budget execution 
https://date.gov.md/ckan/ro/dataset/15071-raport-privind-executarea-bugetului-public-national
4) Budget execution data visualization
https://buget.mf.gov.md/ro#bpn

indicators.justification:
The electronic public procurement system of Moldova MTender is a multi-platform networking digital procurement service comprising a government-operated web portal and the Open Data central database unit. Besides that, it is networking with several commercial electronic platforms certified to support electronic tendering procedures for public sector and commercial clients. (1)

The MTender platform started being developed by the MoF with the support of the EBRD in the
framework of a Memorandum between the competent authorities, the private sector, and civil society
that was signed on November 30, 2016. The current MTender system started working at the beginning of
2017 as a pilot project for small value procurement. While the old system was still in place, the contracting authorities had the right to decide to carry out electronically small value procurement through the new system. A year and a half later, in October 2018, the new electronic system became mandatory for conducting procurement, despite a number of technical shortcomings, including the
limitation to only two of the procedures provided for in the Public Procurement Law (PPL), carried out through electronic auctions,
with price as the only award criterion.
The effort has nevertheless continued to improve the system so that it would cover the entire procurement
cycle, from planning to contract management, allowing the contracting authorities to conduct any
procurement activity or procedure regulated by the PPL. (2)

indicators.justification:
The open government data initiative was first launched in 2012. The initiative is still in a way active through the open data government portal date.gov.md. The portal was modernized in 2019, when besides the open data module, two more were added, one offering the possibility to search through some state registries and one offering authorized access to data. (1)


The open data initiative is an important part of the OGP National Action Plan of the Government of Moldova. The latest National Action Plan for Open Government (2018-2019) includes a commitment about increasing access to information and use of open data. This commitment includes activities on both access to information and open data. Ensuring access to information and promoting the use of open data by citizens, publishing open data on the governmental portal http://www.date.gov.md, following the open data standards are some of the milestones included.(2)

However, there is no evidence that there is an active open data initiative with a defined action plan and strategy. The Republic of Moldova Transitional Results Report 2019-2020 mentions that "despite the restructuring of the date.gov.md portal, several deficiencies remain. These include a lack of clarity on which data public authorities must publish on the platform, the ownership of the platform, and the search function and data update policy. There are also no common standards for publishing data on the platform, and the available data is often of questionable relevance to users and stakeholders. (3)

indicators.justification:
The Law on personal data protection was adopted in 2011, undergoing some changes over the years. This law creates the legal framework necessary for the application of Directive 95/46 / EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 24 October 1995 on the protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal data and on the free movement of such data. The purpose of this law is to ensure the protection of the fundamental rights and freedoms of the natural person with regard to the processing of personal data, in particular the right to the inviolability of private, family, and private life. (1) 

However, there is always a debate regarding data protection and personal data that can be of public interest. The national authorities often interpret in a restrictive manner the provisions enshrined in the Law on the Protection of Personal Data with regard to journalists, which have the constitutional task of informing the public on matters of public interest. Information providers often do not apply the essential criteria of balancing the right to the protection of personal data and the right to freedom of expression and information. In the text of the Law on the protection of personal data, there is no definition of personal data related to the category of information of public interest and personal data that may become information of public interest. (2) 

Sources: 
(1) https://www.legis.md/cautare/getResults?doc_id=126192&lang=ro
(2) http://media-azi.md/sites/default/files/PROTECTIA%20DATELOR%20CU%20CARACTER%20PERSONAL%20VS%20LIBERTATEA%20DE%20EXPRIMARE%20SI%20INFORMARE_0.pdf

indicators.justification:
Information about the open data legal framework of Moldova can be easily found and accessed online in the State register of legal acts. 
In 2014, the Government of Moldova voted for two important documents that set the legal background for open data, Government Decision No. 700 of 25-08-2014 and Government Decision No. 701 of 25-08-2014. The Government Decision 700 of 25-08-2014 clearly establishes the principles of open government data and those of re-use of public information and covers governmental institutions, subordinate administrative authorities at the central level.(1) Decision No. 701 of 25-08-2014 establishes the methodology of publishing open data explains the process of publishing data on the portal date.gov.md.(2)  

Another important document is Law No. 305 of 26-12-2012. This law creates the necessary framework for the application of Directive 2003/98 / EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 17 November 2003 on the re - use of public sector information. (3) Additionally, Government Decision No. 886 of 08-11-2014 sets out the practical aspects of open data, such as machine readable data formats, publishing licenses, etc.(4)

indicators.justification:
The Law on the declaration of wealth and personal interests no. 133 from 17.06.2016 requires that data on the interest and assets of public officials be published within 30 days of the expiry of the time limits for the submission of declarations. The Annexes to this law provide structured forms for data collection that are filled in by subjects of declaration. (1)

The subjects of the declaration who have an electronic signature can submit the declaration of wealth and personal interests in electronic format by accessing the online declaration portal. 

The use of the "e-Integrity" system allows the Authority to simplify procedures for the automatic archiving, verification, and analysis of declarations of assets and personal interests and facilitates the electronic access by interested citizens and institutions to information of public interest. (2)

indicators.justification:
The Electoral code of Moldova, art. (22) pt. 2, mentions that the Central Electoral Commission, as an independent supervisory and control body regarding the financing of political parties and electoral campaigns, ensures collection and publication of reports regarding campaign and party finance. Art. (43) pt. 4 states that the reports shall be placed on the website of the Central Electoral Commission within 48 hours of their receipt, in compliance with the legislation on the protection of personal data. (1) 


The Decision No. 2704 from 17-09-2019
for the approval of the Regulation
on the financing of electoral campaigns
of electoral contestants has separate provisions on the reports related to electoral campaigns. They also have to be published within 48 hours after their receipt. (2)

Data is being published on the Central Electoral Commission, although there is no specific mention in the law about the data formats of the reports on party finances.

indicators.justification:
The Law  No. 239 of 13-11-2008 on transparency in the decision-making process establishes the applicable rules for ensuring transparency in the decision-making process within the central and local public administration authorities, and regulates their relations with citizens, with associations established in accordance with the law, with other stakeholders in order to participate in the decision-making process. (1)

The Decision No. 967 from 09-08-2016 on the public consultation mechanism with civil society in the decision-making process approves the Regulation on public consultation procedures with civil society in the decision-making process. (2)

The legal framework requires that the summary of the received recommendations be placed on the official website of the public authority, be displayed at its headquarters in a space accessible to the public, and/or be disseminated in the central or local media.

Public authorities have to ensure access to adopted decisions by publishing them in the manner established by law by placing them on the official website, by posting at their headquarters in a space accessible to the public, and/or by broadcasting in central or local media.

indicators.justification:
In recent years, there has been an abusive tendency to not disclose information held by public authorities, citing reasons of national security, trade secret, or personal data. It seems that the legislation in force facilitates the secrecy of information and imposes cumbersome procedures for its declassification. This is due to the fact that the existing legislation is outdated and has not been adjusted to the common international standards for ensuring access to information held by public authorities. (1)

A draft proposal registered in 2016 for the modification of the Law on access to information suggested the creation of a special register of records and control of requests regarding
access to information. (2)

The draft was registered in Parliament by a group of Members and was debated at a roundtable, but was rejected. Currently, FOI requests are being registered as petitions, thus there is no separate evidence or control of these requests.

Sources:
1) Report: Ex-post impact assessment on Law no 982/2000 on access to information.
http://www.parlament.md/LinkClick.aspx?fileticket=bTk8rg8l2jI%3D&tabid=104&language=ro-RO

2) Draft law amending and supplementing some legislative acts (Law on access to information)
https://www.parlament.md/ProcesulLegislativ/Proiectedeactelegislative/tabid/61/LegislativId/3118/language/ro-RO/Default.aspx

indicators.justification:
Since data about companies was released in 2014, civil society organizations, as well as private entities, have created portals and data products that are meant to facilitate the use of this data. Originally, data was being published on date.gov.md in large XLS files, but through these portals citizens can easily navigate and look for the information they need. Some examples can be found below. 

Idno.md - a local platform that re-uses open data about companies from Moldova. On this website, the user can check basic information about a company, such as who their founder is, the address, etc., but also track the history of that company and see if something changed throughout the years. (1) 

www.openmoney.md- a website that aims to show who the real beneficiaries of public contracts are. (2)

www.infodebit.md - offers the possibility to verify the quality of potential business partners, evaluate their credibility for the development and/or continuation of sustainable partnerships. (3)

Additionally, investigative journalists are the ones who use this kind of data and products in their investigations. An example is the article of Ziarul de Garda, who conducted an investigation about a company organizing a charter flight for Moldovans during the lockdown in 2020. (4)

Sources: 
1) Idno.md 
https://idno.md/
2) Openmoney.md
https://openmoney.md/
3) Infodebit.md
4) After Paris, Prague? Several Moldovans were stranded at the airport after their flight was canceled 
https://www.zdg.md/stiri/dupa-paris-praga-mai-multi-moldoveni-blocati-la-aeroport-dupa-ce-zborul-le-a-fost-anulat/

indicators.justification:
The civil society has an important role in overseeing the way in which public money is spent and how public procurement is conducted, all in order to ensure transparency. The availability of data about public contracting makes it possible to spot wrongdoings and signal them to the society and responsible institutions. One example in this regard is the petition signed by the coalition of public organizations for observing the principles of transparency and efficiency in the use of public money in a pandemic that called upon the authorities on critical deterioration of transparency in public procurement Healthcare.(1) 


Another example is the Revizia.md tool developed by the NGO AGER. The purpose of this platform is to facilitate civic monitoring of public procurement by identifying possible errors, reporting them, and remedying them by addressing the competent authorities. (2)

At the beginning of the lockdown, a group of civil society organizations created the tender.health platform. Tender.health is an open platform that allows the analysis of data on public procurement in the field of health to combat COVID-19 in the Republic of Moldova. (3)

IDIS Viitorul has created a series of reports and recommendations for the improvement of public procurement in Moldova.(4)
 

Sources: 
1) Civil society call to authorities on critical deterioration of transparency in public procurement by the Center for Centralized Public Procurement in Healthcare

http://www.transparency.md/2020/04/12/civil-society-call-to-authorities-on-critical-deterioration-of-transparency-in-public-procurement-by-the-center-for-centralized-public-procurement-in-healthcare/

2) Revizia.md
https://revizia.md/

3) Tender.health
https://www.tender.health/

4) IDIS Viitorul reports on public procurement in Moldova
http://www.viitorul.org/ro/content/achizi%C8%9Bii-publice
